details.title: System Reliability of a Limited-Flow Network in Multicommodity Case
details.standardTitle: System Reliability of a Limited-Flow Network in Multicommodity Case

p: Yi-Kuei Lin is a full Professor in the Information Management Department, and the Dean of the Management College, Vanung University, Taiwan, Republic of China. He received the B.S. in Applied Mathematics Department from National Chiao Tung University, Taiwan. He obtained the M.S., and the Ph.D. in the Department of Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management at National Tsing Hua University, Taiwan, Republic of China. His research interest includes stochastic network reliability, performance evaluation, project management, and operations research. He has published several papers in refereed journals including IIE Transactions, Reliability Engineering & System Safety, IEEE Transactions on Reliability, European Journal of Operational Research, International Journal of Reliability Quality and Safety Engineering, Computers and Operations Research, Journal of the Operations Research Society of Japan, Computers and Industrial Engineering, International Journal of Industrial Engineering, Mathematical and Computer Modelling, Journal of the Chinese Institute of Engineers, International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology, Computers and Mathematics with Applications, Journal of Chinese Institute of Industrial Engineers, and Journal of Quantitative Management.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Inf. Manage., Vanung Univ, Tao-Yuan
authors.name: Yi-Kuei Lin

details.abstract: Network analysis is an important approach to model real-world systems. System reliability, and system unreliability are two related performance indices useful to measure the quality level of a supply-demand system. For a binary-state network without flow, the system unreliability is the probability that the system can not connect the source and the sink. Extending to a limited-flow network in the single-commodity case, the arc capacity is stochastic, and the system capacity (i.e. the maximum flow) is not a fixed number. The system unreliability for (d+1), the probability that the upper bound of the system capacity equals d, can be computed in terms of upper boundary points. An upper boundary point is the maximal system state such that the system fulfills the demand. This paper concentrates on a multicommodity limited-flow network (MLFN) in which multicommodity are transmitted through unreliable nodes and arcs. Nevertheless, the system capacity is not suitable to be treated as the maximal sum of the commodity because each commodity consumes the capacity differently. We define the system capacity as a demand vector if the system fulfills at most such a demand vector. The main problem of this paper is to measure the quality level of a MLFN. We propose a new performance index, the probability that the upper bound of the system capacity equals the demand vector subject to the budget constraint, to evaluate the quality level of a MLFN. A branch-and-bound algorithm based on minimal cuts is presented to generate all upper boundary points in order to compute the performance index. The computational complexity of the proposed algorithm is analyzed

links.abstract: Very few techniques exist for reliability evaluation of communication systems where links as well as nodes have certain probability of failure. This correspondence describes a technique by which the reliability expression for such a system can be conveniently derived. It is also shown that using the concept of this correspondence, it is possible to extend all the existing reliability-evaluation algorithms to communication systems with little effort.

links.abstract: Many systems can be regarded as flow networks whose arcs have discrete and multi-valued random capacities. The probability of the maximum flow at each various level and the reliability of such a flow network can be calculated in terms of K-lattices which are generated from each subset of the family of all MCs (minimal cutsets). However the size of such a family 2/sup m/-1 (m=number of MCs) grows exponentially with m. Such a flow network can be considered as a multistate system with multistate co...

context.text: Hence, the authors [10], [14], [24], [28] used MC to generate all upper boundary points for \$d\$ in order to evaluate the system unreliability for \$(d+1)\$, the probability that the upper bound of the system capacity equals \$d\$, for the perfect node, single-commodity case.
As in those approaches in [10], [14], [24], [25], [28], we suppose that all MC have been efficiently derived from the algorithms discussed in [2], [4], [23].
It can be calculated by applying methods such as the inclusion-exclusion method [7], [14]–[19]; disjoint subsets [14], [18], [24]; or state-space decomposition [10], [12], [13].

context.text: Without budget constraints, several authors [12], [13], [25], [26] had presented algorithms to evaluate the system reliability, the probability that the lower bound of the system capacity equals the demand \$d\$, for the perfect nodes case.
It can be calculated by applying methods such as the inclusion-exclusion method [7], [14]–[19]; disjoint subsets [14], [18], [24]; or state-space decomposition [10], [12], [13].
In a SLFN, Held & Wolfe [12], and Griffith [21] proved that \$\Pr\{\varphi(X)\leq d\}=1-\Pr\{\varphi(X)\geq d+1\}\$.

context.text: In terms of MP, Lin [15] evaluated the system reliability for the perfect nodes case to fulfill the demand vector \${\bf d}\$, where the system capacity is \${\bf d}\$ if the system meets at most \${\bf d}\$.
Without budget constraints, Lin [15] had proposed an algorithm to evaluate \$\Pr\{V(X)\geq{\bf d}\}\$ for the perfect nodes case in terms of MP.
It can be calculated by applying methods such as the inclusion-exclusion method [7], [14]–[15][19]; disjoint subsets [14], [18], [24]; or state-space decomposition [10], [12], [13].

context.text: The literatures [16], [27], and Yeh [31] extended such a reliability problem to the unreliable nodes case, and the budget constraint case, respectively.
It can be calculated by applying methods such as the inclusion-exclusion method [7], [14]–[16][19]; disjoint subsets [14], [18], [24]; or state-space decomposition [10], [12], [13].
The value \$\Pr\{X\vert V(X)\geq(3,2)\}=0.03969\$ can be obtained by Lin [16], in which only (4,3,3,4,0,1,4,4,) is the lower boundary point for (3,2).

links.abstract: System reliability evaluation for flow networks is an important issue in quality management. This paper concentrates on a stochastic-flow network in which nodes as well as branches have several possible capacities, and can fail. The possibility is evaluated that a given amount of messages can be transmitted through the stochastic-flow network under the budget constraint. Such a possibility, system reliability, is a performance index for a stochastic-flow network. A minimal path, an order sequenc...

context.text: Further, Lin [20] evaluated the reliability problem for the unreliable nodes case under a budget constraint.

links.abstract: The author examines both strategic and detailed issues of applying computer technology in projects to help ensure that the benefits afforded by the technology can be fully realised. The author discusses the technology issues, the system strategy and development, and the benefits of applying computer technology to project management. The author then discusses the project phases and their implementation.

links.abstract: This paper presents an efficient cutset approach to compute the reliability of a large communication network having heterogeneous link capacities. The reliability measure has been defined as capacity related reliability (CRR). The proposed method, subset cut technique (SCT), requires the cutset information of the network. For each minimal cut C/sub i/, and a given minimum bandwidth requirement W/sub min/, the method enumerates all nonredundant subset cut (SC), where each SC relates link capaciti...

links.abstract: Discrete function theory, which extends switching function theory and multiple-valued logic function theory, is introduced into multistate system analysis. Some theoretical conclusions and algorithms which play key roles in multistate system analysis are presented. The concepts of s-coherence and duality in binary-state system analysis are generalized. The set of minimal upper (maximum lower) vectors for level j, which play the role of min path (cut) set, is introduced to represent the states of...

links.abstract: Many real-world systems are multistate and composed of multistate components in which the reliability can be computed in terms of the lower bound points of level d, called d-minpaths (d-MP). Such systems (electric power, transportation, etc.) may be regarded as flow networks whose arcs have statistically independent, discrete, limited and multivalued random capacities. This study focuses on how to find the entire path of d-MP before calculating the reliability of an acyclic network. Analysis of ...
